form.longName: PhenX PX090201 - Arterial Blood Gas Abg
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol describes the procedures for blood collection for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. It involves puncturing an artery with a thin needle and syringe and drawing a small volume of blood. The most common puncture site is the radial artery at the wrist, but sometimes the femoral artery in the groin or other sites are used.

headerInstruction.text: Blood is drawn anaerobically from a peripheral artery (radial, brachial, femoral, or dorsalis pedis) via a single percutaneous needle puncture, or from an indwelling arterial cannula or catheter for multiple samples. Either method provides a b..TRUNCATED

form.longName: PhenX PX090401 - Chest Computed Tomography Ct
form.preferredDefinition: A chest computed tomography (CT) is a non-invasive test that shows the size, shape, and structure of the lungs and other structures in the thorax. The chest CT scanning machine takes many pictures, called slices, of the lungs and the inside of the chest. A computer processes these pictures to be viewed on a monitor or printed on film. The computer can also stack the pictures to create a very detailed, three-dimensional (3D) model of the organs. This three-dimensional digital information can be used to measure the dimensions of the structure, such as the bronchial tree, or the density of the structure, such as the lung parenchyma. It is very important that the CT scanner used in any clinical research study be calibrated regularly against calibration standards that are provided by the manufacturer or in some instances by the study itself.

question.questionText: Conditions that might affect ability to comply with breathing instructions (conditions_affecting_breathing)

Supine Expiratory CT Image ID (expiratory_ct_image_id)
Inspiratory CT table image (inspir_table_png)
Expiratory CT table image (expir_table_png)

form.longName: PhenX PX081201 - Presence Of Dental Fluorosis
form.preferredDefinition: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface.

question.questionText: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface. To obtain the Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF), each fully erupted, unrestored tooth surface is examined and assigned a score on a 0 to 7 scale noted below. This score is assigned to the posterior tooth Upper Right 3M from the buccal aspect. (dental_fluorosis_ur3m_buccal_tsif)

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).
validValue.description: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).
validValue.description: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).

validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).
validValue.description: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).

validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least two-thirds of the visible surface (Score = 3).
validValue.description: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least two-thirds of the visible surface (Score = 3).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).
validValue.description: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).

validValue.meaningText: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. A pit is defined as a definite physical defect in the enamel surface with a rough floor that is surrounded by a wall of intact enamel. The pitted area is usually stained or differs in color from the surrounding enamel (Score = 5).
validValue.description: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. A pit is defined as a definite physical defect in the enamel surface with a rough floor that is surrounded by a wall of intact enamel. The pitted area is usually stained or differs in color from the surrounding enamel (Score = 5).

validValue.meaningText: Both discrete pitting and staining of the intact enamel exist (Score = 6).
validValue.description: Both discrete pitting and staining of the intact enamel exist (Score = 6).

validValue.meaningText: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).
validValue.description: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).

validValue.meaningText: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).
validValue.description: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).

validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).
validValue.description: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).

validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least two-thirds of the visible surface (Score = 3).
validValue.description: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least two-thirds of the visible surface (Score = 3).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).
validValue.description: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).

validValue.meaningText: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. A pit is defined as a definite physical defect in the enamel surface with a rough floor that is surrounded by a wall of intact enamel. The pitted area is usually stained or differs in color from the surrounding enamel (Score = 5).
validValue.description: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. validValue.meaningText: Both discrete pitting and staining of the intact enamel exist (Score = 6).
validValue.description: Both discrete pitting and staining of the intact enamel exist (Score = 6).

validValue.meaningText: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).
validValue.description: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).

question.questionText: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface. To obtain the Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF), each fully erupted, unrestored tooth surface is examined and assigned a score on a 0 to 7 scale noted below. This score is assigned to the posterior tooth Lower Right 2M from the occlusal aspect. (dental_fluorosis_lr2m_occlusal_tsif)

To obtain the Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF), each fully erupted, unrestored tooth surface is examined and assigned a score on a 0 to 7 scale noted below. This score is assigned to the posterior tooth Lower Right 1B from the occlusal aspect. (dental_fluorosis_lr1b_occlusal_tsif)

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).
validValue.description: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).

The pitted area is usually stained or differs in color from the surrounding enamel (Score = 5).
validValue.description: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. validValue.meaningText: Both discrete pitting and staining of the intact enamel exist (Score = 6).

validValue.meaningText: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).
validValue.description: Confluent pitting of the enamel surface exists. Large areas of enamel may be missing and the anatomy of the tooth may be altered. Dark-brown stain is usually present (Score = 7).

question.questionText: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface. To obtain the Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF), each fully erupted, unrestored tooth surface is examined and assigned a score on a 0 to 7 scale noted below. This score is assigned to the posterior tooth Upper Left 1B from the lingual aspect. (dental_fluorosis_ul1b_lingual_tsif)

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).
validValue.description: Enamel shows no evidence of fluorosis (Score = 0).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. This category includes fluorosis confined only to incisal edges of anterior teeth and cusp tips of posterior teeth ("snowcapping") (Score = 1).
validValue.description: Enamel shows definite evidence of fluorosis, namely areas with parchment-white color that total less than one-third of the visible enamel surface. validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).

question.questionText: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface. validValue.meaningText: Parchment-white fluorosis totals at least one-third of the visible surface, but less than two-thirds (Score = 2).

validValue.meaningText: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).
validValue.description: Enamel shows staining in conjunction with any of the preceding levels of fluorosis. Staining is defined as an area of definite discoloration that may range from light to very dark brown (Score = 4).

validValue.meaningText: Discrete pitting of the enamel exists, unaccompanied by evidence of staining of intact enamel. A pit is defined as a definite physical defect in the enamel surface with a rough floor that is surrounded by a wall of intact enamel. The pitted area is usually stained or differs in color from the surrounding enamel (Score = 5).

question.questionText: The Tooth Surface Index of Fluorosis (TSIF) assesses dental fluorosis for each tooth surface.
